items.title: N-Uniform Third Derivative Bound for Fitness (PROVEN)
items.content:
803: :label: thm-fitness-third-deriv-proven
804: 
805: **From Theorem `thm-c3-main-preview` in [stability/c3_geometric_gas.md](13_geometric_gas_c3_regularity.md):**
806: 
807: Under natural smoothness assumptions:
808: 1. Squashing function $g_A \in C^3$ with $\|g_A'''\|_\infty < \infty$
809: 2. Localization kernel $K_\rho \in C^3$ with appropriate bounds
810: 3. Distance function $d \in C^3(T^3)$
811: 4. Regularized standard deviation $\sigma'_{\text{reg}} \in C^3$
812: 
813: the fitness potential satisfies:
814: 
815: $$
816: \sup_{x \in T^3, S \in \Sigma_N} \|\nabla^3_{x} V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho](x)\| \leq K_{V,3}(\rho) < \infty
817: $$
818: 
819: where $K_{V,3}(\rho)$ is **k-uniform and N-uniform** (independent of alive walker count and total swarm size).
items.raw_directive:
800: **Conclusion:** If the kernel $K_\rho$ and distance $d$ are both $C^3$, then $\|\nabla^3 V_{\text{fit}}\| \leq C''_{\text{fit}}(\rho)$ with $C''_{\text{fit}}(\rho)$ **independent of N**.
801:

items.label: thm-qsd-poincare-rigorous
items.title: N-Uniform Poincaré Inequality for QSD Velocities (CORRECTED PROOF)
items.content:
883: :label: thm-qsd-poincare-rigorous
884: 
885: The quasi-stationary distribution $\pi_N$ for the Geometric Gas with **normalized viscous coupling** satisfies a Poincaré inequality in velocity:
886: 
887: $$
888: \text{Var}_{\pi_N}(g) \leq C_P(\rho) \sum_{i=1}^N \int |\nabla_{v_i} g|^2 d\pi_N
889: $$
890: 
891: where:
892: 
893: $$
894: C_P(\rho) \leq \frac{c_{\max}^2(\rho)}{2\gamma}
895: $$
896: 
897: is **independent of N** for all $\nu > 0$.
898: 
899: Here:
900: - $c_{\max}(\rho) = 1/(\epsilon_\Sigma - H_{\max}(\rho))$ from uniform ellipticity
items.raw_directive:
880: **Note on correlations:** The QSD is not exactly a product measure (there are correlations from viscous coupling). However, as proven rigorously in Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-qsd-poincare-rigorous` below, the **normalized viscous coupling** ensures the Poincaré constant remains N-uniform for **all $\nu > 0$** (no upper bound required).
881: 
882: :::{prf:theorem} N-Uniform Poincaré Inequality for QSD Velocities (CORRECTED PROOF)
883: :label: thm-qsd-poincare-rigorous
884: 
885: The quasi-stationary distribution $\pi_N$ for the Geometric Gas with **normalized viscous coupling** satisfies a Poincaré inequality in velocity:
886: 
887: $$
888: \text{Var}_{\pi_N}(g) \leq C_P(\rho) \sum_{i=1}^N \int |\nabla_{v_i} g|^2 d\pi_N
889: $$
890: 
891: where:
892: 
893: $$
894: C_P(\rho) \leq \frac{c_{\max}^2(\rho)}{2\gamma}
895: $$
896: 
897: is **independent of N** for all $\nu > 0$.
898: 
899: Here:
900: - $c_{\max}(\rho) = 1/(\epsilon_\Sigma - H_{\max}(\rho))$ from uniform ellipticity
901: - The normalized viscous coupling $\mathbf{F}_{\text{viscous}} = \nu \sum_j [K(x_i-x_j)/\deg(i)](v_j - v_i)$ produces a graph Laplacian with eigenvalues in $[0,2]$ independent of $N$

items.label: thm-drift-perturbation-bounds
items.title: N-Uniform Drift Perturbation Bounds
items.content:
1068: :label: thm-drift-perturbation-bounds
1069: 
1070: The adaptive and viscous forces satisfy the following N-uniform bounds:
1071: 
1072: 1. **Adaptive force bound:**
1073: 
1074: $$
1075: \|\mathbf{F}_{\text{adapt}}(x_i, S)\| \leq \epsilon_F F_{\text{adapt,max}}(\rho)
1076: $$
1077: 
1078: where $F_{\text{adapt,max}}(\rho) < \infty$ is given explicitly by Theorem A.1 ({prf:ref}`thm-c1-regularity`) in Appendix A of `07_geometric_gas.md`.
1079: 
1080: 2. **Normalized viscous force bound:**
1081: 
1082: $$
1083: \left\|\mathbf{F}_{\text{viscous}}(x_i, S)\right\| = \left\|\nu \sum_{j \neq i} \frac{K(x_i - x_j)}{\deg(i)} (v_j - v_i)\right\| \leq 2\nu \|v\|_{\max}
1084: $$
1085: 
1086: where $\|v\|_{\max}$ is the maximum velocity magnitude (controlled by the QSD ergodicity).
items.raw_directive:

1079: 
1080: 2. **Normalized viscous force bound:**

items.label: thm-cattiaux-guillin-verification
items.title: Verification of Cattiaux-Guillin Hypotheses
items.content:
1125: :label: thm-cattiaux-guillin-verification
1126: 
1127: The generator perturbation
1128: 
1129: $$
1130: \mathcal{L}_{\text{full}} = \mathcal{L}_{\text{backbone}} + \mathcal{V}_{\text{adapt}} + \mathcal{V}_{\text{visc}}
1131: $$
1132: 
1133: satisfies the hypotheses of the Cattiaux-Guillin LSI perturbation theorem:
1134: 
1135: 1. **Invariance:** The QSD $\pi_N$ is invariant under $\mathcal{L}_{\text{full}}$ (by construction of the QSD)
1136: 
1137: 2. **Relative boundedness:** The perturbations are relatively bounded in the Dirichlet form sense:
1138: 
1139: $$
1140: \left|\int \mathcal{V}_{\text{adapt}} f \, d\pi_N\right| \leq \epsilon_F \cdot C_1(\rho) \sqrt{\mathcal{E}(f, f)}
1141: $$
1142: 
1143: $$
1144: \left|\int \mathcal{V}_{\text{visc}} f \, d\pi_N\right| \leq \nu \cdot C_2(\rho) \sqrt{\mathcal{E}(f, f)}
1145: $$
1146: 
1147: where $\mathcal{E}(f, f) = \int |\Sigma_{\text{reg}} \nabla_v f|^2 d\pi_N$ is the Dirichlet form and $C_1(\rho), C_2(\rho)$ are N-uniform.

items.label: thm-adaptive-lsi-main
items.title: N-Uniform Log-Sobolev Inequality for Geometric Viscous Fluid Model
items.content:
1283: :label: thm-adaptive-lsi-main
1284: 
1285: Under the assumptions:
1286: 
1287: 1. **Kernel regularity:** Localization kernel $K_\rho \in C^3$ with $\|\nabla^k K_\rho\| \leq C_K^{(k)}(\rho)/\rho^k$ for $k=1,2,3$
1288: 2. **Distance regularity:** Distance function $d \in C^3(T^3)$
1289: 3. **Squashing regularity:** $g_A \in C^3$ with $\|g_A'''\|_\infty < \infty$
1290: 4. **Parameter regime:** $\epsilon_F < \epsilon_F^*(\rho) = c_{\min}(\rho)/(2F_{\text{adapt,max}}(\rho))$, $\nu > 0$ (arbitrary), $\epsilon_\Sigma > H_{\max}(\rho)$
1291: 
1292: the quasi-stationary distribution $\pi_N$ for the N-particle Geometric Viscous Fluid Model satisfies a Log-Sobolev Inequality:
1293: 
1294: **N-Uniformity:** The LSI constant's independence of $N$ is a direct consequence of the proven N-uniformity of all its constituent components: the ellipticity bounds $c_{\min}(\rho), c_{\max}(\rho)$ ({prf:ref}`thm-ueph-proven`), the C³ regularity bound $K_{V,3}(\rho)$ ({prf:ref}`thm-fitness-third-deriv-proven`), the Poincaré constant $C_P(\rho)$ ({prf:ref}`thm-qsd-poincare-rigorous`), and the Wasserstein contraction rate $\kappa_W$ (Theorem 2.3.1 in `04_convergence.md`).
1295: 
1296: $$
1297: \text{Ent}_{\pi_N}(f^2) \leq C_{\text{LSI}}(\rho) \sum_{i=1}^N \int \|\Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) \nabla_{v_i} f\|^2 d\pi_N
1298: $$
1299: 
1300: where the LSI constant satisfies the explicit bound:
1301: 
1302: $$
1303: C_{\text{LSI}}(\rho) \leq \frac{C_{\text{backbone+clone}}(\rho)}{1 - \epsilon_F \cdot C_1(\rho)}
1304: $$
1305: 
1306: with constituent terms:
1307: 
1308: $$
1309: \begin{aligned}
1310: C_{\text{backbone+clone}}(\rho) &= \frac{C_P(\rho)}{1 - C_{\text{comm}}(\rho)/\alpha_{\text{backbone}}(\rho)} \cdot \frac{1}{1 - \kappa_W^{-1} \delta_{\text{clone}}} \\
1311: C_P(\rho) &= \frac{c_{\max}^2(\rho)}{2\gamma} \quad \text{(Poincaré constant from {prf:ref}`thm-qsd-poincare-rigorous`)} \\
1312: \alpha_{\text{backbone}}(\rho) &= \min(\gamma, \kappa_{\text{conf}}) \quad \text{(hypocoercive gap)} \\
1313: C_{\text{comm}}(\rho) &= \frac{C_{\nabla\Sigma}(\rho)}{c_{\min}(\rho)} \leq \frac{K_{V,3}(\rho)}{c_{\min}(\rho)} \quad \text{(commutator error from {prf:ref}`thm-fitness-third-deriv-proven`)} \\
1314: C_1(\rho) &= \frac{F_{\text{adapt,max}}(\rho)}{c_{\min}(\rho)} \quad \text{(adaptive force perturbation constant)}
1315: \end{aligned}
1316: $$
1317: 
1318: This constant is **uniformly bounded for all $N \geq 2$**:
1319: 
1320: $$
1321: \sup_{N \geq 2} C_{\text{LSI}}(N, \rho) \leq C_{\text{LSI}}^{\max}(\rho) < \infty
1322: $$
items.section: ## 9. Main Theorem: N-Uniform LSI for Geometric Gas
items.raw_directive:
1280: ### 9.1. Statement of the Theorem
1281: 
1282: :::{prf:theorem} N-Uniform Log-Sobolev Inequality for Geometric Viscous Fluid Model
1283: :label: thm-adaptive-lsi-main
1284: 
1285: Under the assumptions:
1286: 
1287: 1. **Kernel regularity:** Localization kernel $K_\rho \in C^3$ with $\|\nabla^k K_\rho\| \leq C_K^{(k)}(\rho)/\rho^k$ for $k=1,2,3$
1288: 2. **Distance regularity:** Distance function $d \in C^3(T^3)$
1289: 3. **Squashing regularity:** $g_A \in C^3$ with $\|g_A'''\|_\infty < \infty$
1290: 4. **Parameter regime:** $\epsilon_F < \epsilon_F^*(\rho) = c_{\min}(\rho)/(2F_{\text{adapt,max}}(\rho))$, $\nu > 0$ (arbitrary), $\epsilon_\Sigma > H_{\max}(\rho)$
1291: 
1292: the quasi-stationary distribution $\pi_N$ for the N-particle Geometric Viscous Fluid Model satisfies a Log-Sobolev Inequality:
1293: 
1294: **N-Uniformity:** The LSI constant's independence of $N$ is a direct consequence of the proven N-uniformity of all its constituent components: the ellipticity bounds $c_{\min}(\rho), c_{\max}(\rho)$ ({prf:ref}`thm-ueph-proven`), the C³ regularity bound $K_{V,3}(\rho)$ ({prf:ref}`thm-fitness-third-deriv-proven`), the Poincaré constant $C_P(\rho)$ ({prf:ref}`thm-qsd-poincare-rigorous`), and the Wasserstein contraction rate $\kappa_W$ (Theorem 2.3.1 in `04_convergence.md`).
1295: 
1296: $$
1297: \text{Ent}_{\pi_N}(f^2) \leq C_{\text{LSI}}(\rho) \sum_{i=1}^N \int \|\Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) \nabla_{v_i} f\|^2 d\pi_N
1298: $$
1299: 
1300: where the LSI constant satisfies the explicit bound:
1301: 
1302: $$
1303: C_{\text{LSI}}(\rho) \leq \frac{C_{\text{backbone+clone}}(\rho)}{1 - \epsilon_F \cdot C_1(\rho)}
1304: $$
1305: 
1306: with constituent terms:
1307: 
1308: $$
1309: \begin{aligned}
1310: C_{\text{backbone+clone}}(\rho) &= \frac{C_P(\rho)}{1 - C_{\text{comm}}(\rho)/\alpha_{\text{backbone}}(\rho)} \cdot \frac{1}{1 - \kappa_W^{-1} \delta_{\text{clone}}} \\
1311: C_P(\rho) &= \frac{c_{\max}^2(\rho)}{2\gamma} \quad \text{(Poincaré constant from {prf:ref}`thm-qsd-poincare-rigorous`)} \\
1312: \alpha_{\text{backbone}}(\rho) &= \min(\gamma, \kappa_{\text{conf}}) \quad \text{(hypocoercive gap)} \\
1313: C_{\text{comm}}(\rho) &= \frac{C_{\nabla\Sigma}(\rho)}{c_{\min}(\rho)} \leq \frac{K_{V,3}(\rho)}{c_{\min}(\rho)} \quad \text{(commutator error from {prf:ref}`thm-fitness-third-deriv-proven`)} \\
1314: C_1(\rho) &= \frac{F_{\text{adapt,max}}(\rho)}{c_{\min}(\rho)} \quad \text{(adaptive force perturbation constant)}
1315: \end{aligned}
1316: $$
1317: 
1318: This constant is **uniformly bounded for all $N \geq 2$**:
1319: 
1320: $$
1321: \sup_{N \geq 2} C_{\text{LSI}}(N, \rho) \leq C_{\text{LSI}}^{\max}(\rho) < \infty
1322: $$
